reviewText:
If you came here for an engaging storyline, as some of the reviewers apparently did, please re-read the title of the game.  There are no plot twists, or emotional dialogues to be found here.  Instead, this game delivers exactly what it promises, an army of Nazi zombies.  What could be more satisfying than this?  Who better to vent your daily frustrations on?  These are not your unfortunate neighbors, family or friends who have been transformed into the walking dead ... no ... they are undead Nazis.

This game is about blowing the crap out of undead Nazis ... period.  Not only that, it also allows you to experience the crap-blowing up close and in slow motion, following your speeding projectile as it snaps bones, punctures organs and otherwise eviscerates the unending legion of menacing corpses.

If you enjoy the idea of purging the world of demonic Nazi zombies, then this is the game for you!

reviewText:
If you haven’t played anything in the Sniper Elite series, what sets them apart from other run-and-gun shooters is the emphasis on over-the-top sniper shots with x-ray cams. The kills feel incredibly satisfying and the reliance on accuracy pushes one to enhance their skill and experiment with the weaponry to find the best player method. What is NOT here is the stealth element of the previous games, nor is it missed.

If you’ve played other zombie games, like Killing Floor or Left 4 Dead, this series emphasizes limited weapon selection, each with different strengths and weaknesses. It also emphasizes slow shambling zombies over fast-moving ones. The mood is set very well in this game, as it does a good job of providing a feel of a destroyed hellish zombie-infested landscape. It is sufficiently creepy, particularly because you know that survival depends on seeing them first and getting a good distance between you and them. As they shamble closer, accuracy matters more making it harder to pull off shots when it matters most, complimenting the major strengths of this game.

No doubt, you’ve read some criticism of this game. Some of the most prominent criticisms are condensed as follows:

Cheap and unambitious.
Monotonous and repetitive gameplay.
Cashgrab.
Unoriginal.
No plot.

While some of these are accurate to a degree, the reality is that even if they *are* true, it shouldn’t scare you away from this title. It is very fun with four people. I could go by each and refute them point by point, but most of these concerns can be alleviated by two counterpoints.

First, this game *is* cheap. The game is $15.00. The average movie ticket is between $7.84 and $8.38 (as of November 2013). At 1 Hour and 30 minutes as the average length of a film, if you get even three hours of enjoyment out of the game, you’ve already gotten more out of it than your average movie (and you can bring your own snacks and be as loud as you like.) It’s not meant to be some gaming magnum opus, and many Triple A releases try too hard to do this, and fail miserably. This is what you might call a “niche market” game… its aimed at a small segment of the gaming community for a modest profit. This is not a bad thing nor is it any more a cashgrab than any other game produced. While it is not for everyone (nor is it meant to be), it is worth the price of admission.

Second, as far as repetitive gameplay, yes it does have this. Every game is repetitive within certain respects, and the lack of a compelling plot or original gameplay elements makes this title’s repetitive nature relatively obvious. You *can* turn off the x-ray mode if it becomes overwhelming (or reduce its frequency) and the repetitive aspects are alleviated if you play with friends. The solo game mode is best enjoyed in small chunks. The shotguns function as shotguns, the sniper rifles function as sniper rifles, and pistols function as pistols. If you get tired of mowing down zombies with these methods, there are relatively few shooter games that will overcome this limitation. However, one should not expect too much innovation from a shooter game. There are precious few shooters that are innovative with regard to combat mechanics, or they’re successful at dressing up this shortcoming by using non-shooter elements. Much like the title implies, what you see is what you get… and what you get is pretty reasonable and fun in the right mindset.

reviewText:
A challenging & atmospheric wave shooter // Recommended for co-op with friends
+ Includes co-operative play, which enhances the entertainment value massively
+ Bullet time and X-ray features are excellently employed, look fantastic, and the frequency can be scaled up or down as the user prefers
+ Points system encourages taking risks with difficult and long-range shots; often does well to increase the feeling of satisfaction earned when eliminating a difficult sniper
+ Loot and cover mechanics are minimalist and practical
+ Gunplay and hit mechanics are all top-notch; everything connects well and feels appropriate
+ The game's atmosphere is absolutely palpable; this is largely enhanced by the shrill screams of the enemy mobs and the dark theme music pervading throughout
+ Levels are well-designed and objectives are clearly marked; one is not likely to get lost while moving about
+ Quality audio design
+ Lighting plays well against the walls, and generally looks excellent in terms of quality
+ Environmental textures are quite detailed; overall visual presentation is adequate

- Plot is nonchalantly presented and woefully underdeveloped
- Characters are as bland as smooth stones; no lines, no reactions, nothing
- Game shows an over-reliance on wave mechanics; gets frustrating and predictable in a hurry
- Realistic lighting is often sacrificed for atmosphere; that is, while the lighting mechanics themselves are done quite well, the colors and tones of the lighting feel extremely out of place and unrealistic
- There is really only one boss, and it is encountered more than once; boss fights are bland and uninspired
- Bodies will, more often than not, disappear a bit too quickly to loot to one's satisfaction or requirements
- Precious little in the way of collectibles and in-game lore; does not lend to a high replay value, save for co-operative play with friends

Bust a zombie gut!
Rebellion returns with some stand-alone content to its successful Sniper Elite series this time featuring everyone's favorite punching bag and brain-gobblers - Zombies. However, we are not just talking about any old Zombie here (particularly those wussy Zombies who keep getting their backsides handed to them by plants) but none other than Nazi Zombies (as if Nazi's weren't nasty enough whilst alive they now torment us as the risen dead). Set in Berlin - the game ditches the serious demeanor of the original campaign in favor of the occult where Hitler has just unleashed legions of the undead in his last bid attempt to salvage the dying embers of his war machine.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=349663511
There are four characters to choose from allowing the player to jump into any number of co-op situations for up to and including four people. Nazi Zombie Army is a game designed solely around having stupid fun with friends and you will need to work together if you plan on making it through these blood drenched streets, sewers and subways. The single player campaign plays out exactly the same as the co-op campaign and is really not where you want to be spending too much of your time. The levels are long and hard and dying in single player and then exiting (even though you have already hit various checkpoints throughout a level) will put you right back at square one killing off any accumulated joy in quite a short frustrating space of time. However, with four players thrown into the mix the game becomes one big chaotic scramble as you try your best to stay alive or keep your other team mates alive all whilst trying to get in that perfect head or torso shot that takes the enemy down immediately.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=349665129
The more players thrown into the mix the more legions of the undead you will face so acting fast and acting quick will save lives here. The game never seems to take itself too seriously, well how serious can you get you when pairing Nazi and Zombie together - but that does not mean the game plays things for camp laughs. If anything the player should feel just that little unsettled not knowing what hoard lies in wait around the corner. Most of the levels are incredibly atmospheric and well designed with ammo stations placed just about right near the time you begin to run out.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=349664299
I was not expecting Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army to be such a looker. From lighting effects to explosion damage the game looks consistently good with high definition textures everywhere. It does come at a price though as Nazi Zombie Army does require quite a recent desktop or laptop with decent GPU and memory to run optimally. The game should last most players roughly between 7- 10 hours depending on how you play (which is expected given the pricing) but there is always the next level of difficulty to tackle once done so there is quite a bit here to keep most gamers entertained for a while.

I really enjoyed this title and I can heartily recommend it to groups of 4 people looking for some cool Zombie sniping action at a reasonable price that manages to also look quite phenomenal and really is a blast to play.

reviewText:
I enjoy the Sniper Elite series, but this game doesn't really compare. It's the arcade version of what a hastily-thrown-together version of a Sniper game might look like. There's really no story to speak of and a decent amount of the content isn't even accessible without a co-op partner or three. The game was clearly designed with that squad-based co-op experience in mind. I didn't really know what I was getting into when I bought it, because had I known that I probably would have avoided it in the first place.

The worst part is that the gameplay seems to have forgotten the name of the series: the emphasis is not on sniping at all. And there aren't any fun stealth moments either. There are far too many zombies at far too close a range. Instead you're much better off using explosives and automatic weapons if you can find them and just going in loud every time, in every situation.

If that's the kind of game you want then I can understand that, but it's not what I wanted from a Sniper game.

This game has some good qualities and some bad qualities. First, the good; there's a lot of action, so that's pretty fun. There's some bullet drop for the sniper rifles, right on. The game rewards loot hunters, you'll find guns/ammo all over. The selection of firearms is quite good, something like 20 if I recall correctly. It's interesting being able to set up traps. The slow-mo hits are cool, it's a creepy and stressful game, as well as EXTREMILY difficult sometimes. I won't spoil anything but... that... friggin... church.

I think that covers the good, now for the not so good; the MP40 fires too fast, SVT40 fires too slow, STG44 is too weak, M91/30's (Mosin Nagant) front sight is actually a Kar98k front sight, and the M1903's stock looks like a hybrid between a No.4 Lee Enfield and an M1917. From what I can tell, none of the scopes are accurate to real life. I find the special infected can be quite annoying, there is a serious lack of stealth for a sniper game, there is a serious lack of sniping for a sniper game (rarely go beyond 100m. Rarely go beyond 50m for that matter), one of my biggest gripes is there's no FPS option thus no aim down the sights option, and my last issue so far is I've been playing for roughly 2 hours now and it seems to be the same thing over and over:

*SPOILERS* Fight a wave that instantly knows where you are. Fight another wave that instantly knows where you are. Fight another wave or two in the same manner. Find a safe house, restock on supplies, maybe change firearms. Fight a wave that instantly knows where you are. Fight a wave of jogging skeletons that instantly know where you are, fight a sniper who can jump better than spider man, fight another wave that instantly knows where you are. Safe house. Somewhere along the line is the friggin church. Maybe I'm just bad at 3rd person shooters, but I tried about a half dozen times to beat that friggin checkpoint with the MGing tank nazi, and I'm only on marksman (Normal).

Draw your own conclusions. Want action? Perfect. Want realism with your shooting? Keep looking, or check out Red Orchestra.

reviewText:
It's Sniper Elite with zombies. You might have played the previous Sniper Elite games. They're both awesome sniper games. And that's the area where this Sniper Elite doesn't work all that well. It works reasonably well in the larger (outside) areas, but when you're fighting in narrow hallways and tunnels it kinda falls flat on its face. Yes, I know, if the whole team is sniping, there's no way you can die, right ? True. But at least make the weapons for these sections enjoyable to use. Most of them are spray and pray and it takes a crazy amount of bullets to put down just one enemy, let alone massive groups during the more intense firefights. The sniping part is enjoyable as always, and the x-ray cam is just awesome, but is shown too frequently at times.

The game has a  total of 5 levels. They're all quite big and it's hard to complete any of them on your own. So it's best played with a group of 4 people. It's also the most fun this way.

However, the party mechanic could use some work. There are massive amounts of idle hosts, and searching for an existing game practically always leads to you re-entering this very same idle party, which is frustrating and annoying. That, and there are some rage quiters so halfway or near the end of a level someone might leave and if it's the host you'll return back to the main menu, which, well... which sucks !

In the end I did have fun with it, but it happened too often that the host left in my last couple of games. It's the reason I stopped playing. Pity.

I'm skewed with Nazi Zombie Army. And the boss fights, good god they are terrible. If you're not endlessly spamming bullets in to an 8 foot zombie with a Machine Gun that can down all 4 of you in a minute you're fighting a 30 foot ghost who you damage by shooting incredibly fast moving skulls. Sound fun? No it bloody isn't.

I haven't even mentioned the screaming suicide Zombies who run straight up to you in an attempt to blow themselves up. Hilarious as it might be, the typical AI quirks the zombies show like being unable to walk in a straight line because of pathing issues make this INCREDIBLY frustrating when something moving at 50 miles an hour that can instantly kill you can't be easily dispatched because he doesn't know which side of the pavement looks prettier.

Unless you are the BIGGEST Sniper Elite fan or you're just hopelessly drunk and want to see rotting lungs be punctured for hours on end, I really can't recommend this wholeheartedly.

reviewText: Sniper Elite: Spooky Skeleton Army, and it's sequel, Rise of the Skeleton Lord, chronicle the true events of Adolf Hitler's rise to power over the skeleton army during the Fall of Berlin in World War II. Rebellion Developments took their time painstakingly recreating real-life locales and events in which the Bone Battles of Berlin took place. Skeleton warriors rattle and shake as they attempt to prevent the Allies from stealing all of their gold and dairy products, the sources of their skeleton powers. This hyper-realistic simulation game isn't without its flaws and inaccuracies, however. For instance, alongside the teeming skeleton hordes that haunt and spook the German villas and countrysides, you'll often encounter groups of undead Wehrmacht soldiers lumbering around. While there were indeed Nazis occupying the area at the time, any historian worth his salt will tell you that zombies weren't deployed in battle until the Korean War. They were more than likely added for gameplay reasons, as battling only skeletons would be far too difficult or frightening for any reasonable player. Overall the game is a fun, realistic, and enlightening depiction of some of the lesser-known events of World War II, and well worth the $15 price tag.\n\n2spoopy/10

reviewText:
This game's alright, it's pretty dumb as you're using sniper rifles on zombies (I suppose anybody looking for that game where snipers don't suck against zombies this'd be amazing for them.) and the graphics aren't that amazing even on higher settings, anyhow the maps are fairly well detailed as you'll see alot of war torn buildings along with very few corpses that aren't moving and plenty of dead trees but fairly green shrubs, and a deathly fog that covers the entire game and makes it all the less visable.

Anyhow besides the snipers and lack of interesting atmosphere lets get to the good and the bad things that might be worth checking into :

There's a plentiful amount of ammo around the map even for harder difficulties so unless you don't belong behind a sniper rifle then you won't have to worry about it's ammo, luckily there's not just snipers as there's SMG's such as the Thompson or MP40 that's amazing for CQC and the pistols for when you've sprayed your last clip out.

Zombies are tough buggers but are in variety which keep it interesting for some, a good example is if you get far enough into the game you'll find skeletons which aren't killed by headshot but rather a shot to the clear as daylight heart and it'll fall apart in seconds and there's plenty more I won't spoil in this review.

Last good thing is the fact it's co-op, there's really not much to this as it's like L4D2 where if your buddies get downed you're likely screwed too but if you can keep you and your team from getting horded then you'll breeze through.

The first real game breaking thing I have about this game (Which is more of a good yet bad thing) is despite the sniper killcam you'll get often, you cannot kill anything without headshots (Excluding skeletons) and they'll just revive and laugh at your wasted shot.

Some zombies carry guns, and shoot them with extreme accuracy.

There's loadouts still but everything's unlocked as you start, the only gun you have to find to use is the shotty otherwise like I said everything's unlocked and gets fairly annoying without any incentive to continue through the game.

Last but not least the story's thinner than wet paper, It's likely you will find more depth of story and character development in call of duty's games.

This game deserves a 4.7/10

reviewText:
Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is a third-person shooter which focuses on cooperative up to four players, albeit it can be beaten in singleplayer too. It was developed by Rebellion and released in 2013. It's a spin-off title of Sniper Elite V2 and one would say that it feels like mod or DLC to it.

A thing to note is that when they released Nazi Zombie Army 2 they backported changes from it to the first game. That means that now you have all the grain effects, zombies have yellow shiny eyes and the Preacher weapon got changed. The Preacher always looked like a good old double shotgun, but in original version it actually was some kind of double-rifle, shooting very strong single bullet. Ever since the update it now behaves the way it looks - boomstick.
Kinda shame, as I would have prefered if the first game was kept unique compared to sequel.

Multiplayer community appears to be quite alive. From what little time I tried it, it would always find one lobby. And after a while it would get filled with few more players. Yes, they can join even when the game is in the process. But I guess that there may be times when there isn't anybody playing.

And yes, in this game you go through the linear levels and sometimes get locked into area during siege event. And yep, no plot, pretty much. Aside from Hitler released evil somehow and now you have to escape Berlin over 5 levels. Maybe Fegelein will know how to stop him in a sequel, hmm. And yes, you shoot many zombies. And skeletons.

One thing for sure, it has an awesome setting, even if it may get old. It's like a zombie-demons B-Movie old cheesy experience, you can tell that developers weren't taking themselves seriously. Tons of slow slumbering zombies to headshot. reviewText:
I've never played any other Sniper Elite game before so this review shouldn't be biased by comparisons to older/newer games of the series.

In short, yes, I liked the game. A lot.
Definitely would recommend you to buy it although it would be nice to get the game with at least 10~25% off.

It's a pretty simple and straight foward game, you just need to go from point A to point B and kill the zombies along the way.
There are some little twists here and there, like when you'll need to hold your position and kill hordes of zombies trying to siege your position or some boss battles.

Even though all the levels are pretty much linear I really enjoyed how they were crafted specially for the use of sniper rifles. There are lots of open spaces, long corridors and high places where you'll find yourself being able to effectively shoot zombies in the head all the time.

By the way killing zombies, the central point of the game, feels nice. You may get sick of it if you play the game for more than 3~4 hours straight, though. But overall killing zombies in this game is really satisfying.

It took me about 10 hours to finish the game on normal difficulty on single player mode. The game has a lot of replayability and also a focus on co-op with 3 other players but unfortunately I don't have any friends so I can't say much about the co-op.
I'll definitely play through it again in the future.

Summing up: In spite of the game feeling incomplete, it is a great game with a lot of replayability. It may get monotonous after a while but I definitely recommend it, mainly if you enjoy sniper rifles or games like Left 4 Dead and killing floor.
If possible, buy it when it's in sale.

reviewText:
I would like to write a glowing review about this game, about how fun it is to kill Nazi Zombies. But I can't.

Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army sounds great when you say it out loud. It looks great written or typed.
While Nazi Zombie Army sounds like a great idea to improve an already great game, it completely fails here. SE:NZA should be a great game, but sadly, it isn't.

Everything that made Sniper Elite fun - is missing. There's no setup, no planning, no eliminating the odd patrolling enemy to get closer to your target, no setting up traps. Its just a 3rd person corridor shooter with a Sniper rifle, 10 mags of ammo, a SMG and 2 spare magazines, and your handgun and a dozen spare mags.

reviewText:
I have to admit, I wasn't impressed with Sniper Elite V2. It lacked a decent story and had limited gameplay. Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is what Sniper Elite V2 should have been. It’s just so much better killing hordes of zombies instead of a few sparse groups of Nazis. The same weapons are present (+ a few new ones I think), and the same equipment is available. Gameplay is identical to Sniper Elite V2 which fits in nicely to the survival genre. The enemies are more varied, some are suicidal, some are over-sized, some are extremely fast. There’s a good diversity to fight, and plenty of weapons to use (mostly rifles of course). The rifles don’t differ that much, some hit harder, some fire faster, but all of them kill zombies effectively. The bullet cam returns with it’s amazing x-ray kill shot  mode, this time with a decaying zombie corpse!

There’s a single player campaign which is fun to play, but the co-op campaign is where you get your real money’s worth. Enemy density is determined by how many players are in the match, so 2 players means a challenge, and 4 players means prepare for a massacre :P It really is fun to battle the zombie apocalypse alongside friends. The levels are linear, but quite large to allow different options and vantage points for all players. With only 5 missions, the campaign won’t last long, but Sniper Elite difficulty will have you coming back if you’re thirsty for a challenge.

A great standalone game that was worth the pre-order, and something that I‘ll be playing with friends until that ♥♥♥♥♥y elite difficulty has been beaten.

Okay gue bakalan review dengan bahasa Indonesia. Duh, gue orang Indonesia.

SKOR: 6 dari 10
Detailnya...

Kesan pertama: LAG! yup, entah kenapa game ini lag banget di laptop gue. Settingnya pada saat itu reso 1366 dan HIGH. FPS nya bisa mencapai 5-10. Bener bener unplayable. Gue search di forum dan google, ternyata benar... seri ini bisa dibilang 'tidak terlalu' support dengan laptop. So gue musti nurunin reso sampai 800 dan LOW. Akhirnya bisa stabil di 30-40fps. Tapi setelah beberapa misi, akhirnya perlahan gue naikin reso-nya sampai 1200 dan bisa stabil di 30-40fps. Bug? entah lah...

Grafik: pada dasarnya suasananya bener bener terasa banget perang dunia ke dua. Bangunan hancur, gelap, dan mistis mistis begitu. Banyak juga korban perang dan berbagai macam api dari bangunan yang hancur. Detail nya juga cukup kuat, banyak banget darah dan berbagai macam ornamen seperti ketika zaman tahun 1940an, mulai dari buku-buku tua, perabotan, bentuk gedung, dan berbagai macam alat perang lainnya. Point yang paling menakjubkan adalah KILL CAM. Sensasi ketika lo menembak headshot zombie secara slow motion itu bener-bener-BENER memuaskan banget.

Gameplay: BORING! Dari awal sampai akhir tugas lo adalah mengambil senjata, mengisi peluru, dan menembak zombie. Misinya pun cuman 'disuruh kesana, ambil item, dan survive'. Dari awal game sampai akhir game begitu. Bahkan senjatanya pun tidak begitu berpengaruh. So far gue berani bilang senjatanya mirip semua. Rifle, secondary rifle, dan hand gun. Walau pun ada granade, mine, dsb buat gue gak begitu berpengaruh. Gameplay juga kurang begitu memicu adrenalin karena kebanyakan waktu adalah lo mencari tempat yang aman untuk bertahan, lalu menembaki zombie yang BERJALAN menunu diri lo. Memang sih ada beberapa zombie yang mempunyai kemampuan spesial tapi buat gue... piece of cake. OMG CONTROL-NYA SUSAH BANGET. Entah kenapa aim nya begitu susah. Heloooooo ini game sniping lho... kalau aim nya susah, gimana mau headshot? bukan karena kurang/terlalu sensitif, tapi bener bener... GAK BANGET.

Story: LAME! Cerita dari game ini bener bener sama sekali gak kuat. Gak ada background nya dan narasinya kurang. Seakan akan game ini itu membeli 'lisensi' untuk menggunakan nama NAZI lalu... selesai. Serius. Gitu doang.

Skor yang gue berikan adalah 6.
Kenapa? Karena masih cukup menghibur dengan grafik dan KILL CAM nya. Yup, pada dasarnya cuman dua itu doang yang ditawarkan oleh game ini.

Apakah pantas dibeli dengan harga $14?
BIG NO! Dengan uang segitu lo bisa membeli game yang JAUUUUUH lebih keren daripada game ini. Saran gue, lo sebaiknya membeli game ini ketika harganya didiskon hingga menjadi kurang dari $5.

reviewText:
Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is a game that does not care about singleplayer. Where 95% of the time you kill a zombie with a rifle you will have to watch a five-eight second long bullet cam. It's cool the first few times but having to choose from never seeing it at all or seeing it with every single kill aren't exactly ideal options.

Regarding the controls, I can't really complain. Pretty decent.
The game has an alright variety of different weapons to use (your main weapon will be a rifle) and traps.
Very few types of enemies.
Creepy and spooky atmosphere and sounds (one of the better things about this game in my opinion).
Nazi Zombie Armys story seems like it could have potentional but falls flat on almost every step of the way. Obviously you're not playing a zombie game for the long, deep and emotional story though (not that this game has one).

Of course, the zombie killing! The reason why you want to play a zombie game. If you're fond of incredibly repetive, long and boring horde modes where literally all you have to do is stand still and shoot at zombies for about 15 minutes, then run for five minutes then stand still and kill zombies for 15 more minutes then this is a game for you.

In all fairness, it is kinda" fun to play with friends but that's it. It's generally just not a good game. Defiently not worth the full price and should only be bought if you plan to play with friends (the main focus of the game).

reviewText:
NOTE: READ BEFORE DISLIKING THE REVIEW.


Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is the spin off series where you don't fight soldiers, but instead you fight Nazi Zombies. Will you want to play this game or will you want to stick to the originals ?

Story wise there's not much story at all. You can play up to 4 different characters who have to escape Berlin which is filled with Zombies Hitler woke up from the dead, it's just absurd as it sounds.

Gameplay wise it's an identical re skin of Sniper Elite V2. Nothing is changed. The game now focuses on close quarters combat. Trust me when I say this. It's not fun when a horde of zombies gang up and try to kill you and the only thing you have to defend yourself with is a sniper rifle. The are two types of boss battles. One is a big guy zombie who was  a machine gun and it's best to snipe him from afar and there is a poltergeist type boss which can spawn enemies in the area you are fighting in.

Music is alright for the most part. It feels like a great reference to 80's horror movies and a throwback to classic zombie flicks.

Graphics wise, it's an identical clone to Sniper Elite V2. Even some of the levels are ripped straight from V2. All that is changed is that all levels take place during the night and it has this weird greenish filter on top of it.

The game took me 6 hours to finish the entire campaign in Co Op mode.  There is some replay value if you want to find hidden collectibles. Otherwise there is zero replay value.

The game is pretty difficult due to the unfair nature of the enemy placement. I will refer to one of the experiences I had while playing the game. During the 4th mission of the game right before the end of the mission I had to go through a closed door. As soon as I opened it I got downed instantly by 7 zombies before I could even react. Not to mention if you play Co Op you have less checkpoints and if you ♥♥♥♥ up you might have to redo entire sections of a level to get back to the part where you failed.

Level Design is alright for the most part. Some levels have massive open area's in which it's hard to get swarmed which is nice.

The game is incredibly buggy. I had ton's of bugs during the time I played the game. Like enemies glitching through walls. The game not letting me pick up items and more stuff like that.

Overall I wish there was a middle option for this game, cause while I don't find it completely horrible, I don't find it good either. It get's boring really soon and there's a lot wrong with the game. In the end this game is made only for the massive fans of Sniper Elite games. If you are a fan of the Sniper Elite games you will love this game. But I still suggest waiting for a discount before buying this game. I give Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army a 5/10

reviewText:
Maps - Literally just a retextured version of Sniper Elite V2
Gameplay - For being a sniper game, there isn't really any actual proper sniping, like shooting a target 200 metres away. There is none of that apart from shooting the occasional bottle for and achievment.
Variety - A large choice of rifles, sub-machine guns and pistols, although it gives minimal information or stats about each gun so you don't know which to choose for the way you'd like to play (fast but not much damage, do lots of damage but slower paced etc.) In terms of killing things, there isn't alot of variety in that either. You get the zombies with the special abilities (e.g. suicide bombers, ones with more health and such), but apart from that you're basically doing the same thing over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again. Also very short game.
There's sweet kill cams like in every sniper elite game, but If you want kill cams, go for Sniper Elite 3 or Sniper Elite V2 as these ones aren't really that good. Plus it's not as satisfying when you get a bullet cam from 2 feet away. But when playing Sniper Elite V2, shooting at an enemy sniper a mile away and then instantly getting the bullet cam is so much better, since
you kind of actually earned the bullet cam instead of getting it every other kill.
Story - There is no dialogue in cutscenes. It's literally just 4 blokes standing around with the same facial expression for each character. Also there is no story
Conclusion - Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army isn't a very good game, since they basically put no effort into making it a different game to the others. It's basically an expansion pack displayed as a whole new different game (when it isn't).
If you like to mindlessly kill zombies over and over again and like to watch bullets penetrate various internal organs and testicles, then this game is for you. But if you want a better Sniper experience, then I would go for the actually sniper games (Sniper Elite V2 or 3)

Kiss realism goodbye, because this game does not give two sheits about plausibility.

While the campaign may only have a few levels, each one of those levels is a good length with a variety of ways to maim, maul and murderize the opposing undead, ranging from blowing them up with dynamite to making their heads explode with your side arm. Ammo is harder to find for some weapons, so constantly relying on your submachine gun and sidearm can sometimes get you into a tight spot.

Headshots are really the only way to ensure the undead stay dead, lest they comeback to life. There are certain areas where what appear to be already-dead bodies turn out to be not-quite-dead-yet bodies, adding to the level of tension as you have to go around seeking sleeping corpses to put down while conserving your precious ammo. Those zombies you do kill disintegrate after a while, meaning you have to divide your time between fighting and looting ammo before it vanishes.

The enemies in this game aren't particularly varied, what with two basic grunts, one fast-moving suicide bomber, one heavy weapons zombie (which can be real pain in the ♥♥♥ to kill by yourself), one undead sniper variant who can leap tall buildings in a single bound, and one boss. However, the game makes up for this by keeping the spaces tight and only allowing you breathing room when there's about fifty or so enemies trying to kill you.

The Slow-Mo camera is there, and while it does keep the game interesting it can get a little annoying after a while when every kill you make is gratuitously showcased for your carnal boredom.

The only complaints I have are the lack of scenery variety, the lack of enemy variety, and the fact that the characters don't really have much character to grow attached to like their Call of Duty counterparts. These are issues I hope were addressed in this game's sequel. Despite this, Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is still really enjoyable, easily replayable escapist fun.

Kiss realism goodbye, because this game does not give two sheits about plausibility.

While the campaign may only have a few levels, each one of those levels is a good length with a variety of ways to maim, maul and murderize the opposing undead, ranging from blowing them up with dynamite to making their heads explode with your side arm. Ammo is harder to find for some weapons, so constantly relying on your submachine gun and sidearm can sometimes get you into a tight spot.

Headshots are really the only way to ensure the undead stay dead, lest they comeback to life. There are certain areas where what appear to be already-dead bodies turn out to be not-quite-dead-yet bodies, adding to the level of tension as you have to go around seeking sleeping corpses to put down while conserving your precious ammo. Those zombies you do kill disintegrate after a while, meaning you have to divide your time between fighting and looting ammo before it vanishes.

The enemies in this game aren't particularly varied, what with two basic grunts, one fast-moving suicide bomber, one heavy weapons zombie (which can be real pain in the ♥♥♥ to kill by yourself), one undead sniper variant who can leap tall buildings in a single bound, and one boss. However, the game makes up for this by keeping the spaces tight and only allowing you breathing room when there's about fifty or so enemies trying to kill you.

The Slow-Mo camera is there, and while it does keep the game interesting it can get a little annoying after a while when every kill you make is gratuitously showcased for your carnal boredom.

The only complaints I have are the lack of scenery variety, the lack of enemy variety, and the fact that the characters don't really have much character to grow attached to like their Call of Duty counterparts. These are issues I hope were addressed in this game's sequel. Despite this, Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army is still really enjoyable, easily replayable escapist fun.

Sniper Elite: Nazi Zombie Army (NZA) is the vanilla sniper elite 2 modified to play as a zombie game.

There are a dozen or more zombie games available on steam right now, so is NZA worth buying and playing?

Gameplay:

In a word: Yes. NZA Brings the fun marksmanship-oriented gameplay of Sniper Elite 2 into the grim theater of the zombie apocalypse. Third person shooting action and tense long-range sniper battles with zombie snipers. There are horde-attacks that anyone familiar with zombie games will find familiar and challenging. In addition to the regular zombie engagements and horde defense encounters there are boss fights at the end of the level which are challenging and stress marksmanship, time management and mobility.

Misc:

The Menu system is a bit clunky and probably could be more intuitive, but it works.

Playing the game solo is still fun, but the horde engagements and boss fights are really difficult without someone watching your back. I definitely reccomend grabbing a buddy or three and slogging through this one.

Bottom Line:

If you liked sniper elite 2 and left 4 dead, this game is for you. It goes on sale frequently for sub $10 and I think that If you can pick it up for that price-point it's a no brainer, fans of the genre won't be dissapointed purchasing at full market price.

It isn't all that much of a good game either. It's just a little something you and your friends can jump into together for a few hours on a boring, rainy Sunday afternoon. For the cheap price you pay, Nazi Zombie Army is not at all a bad purchase in its own right. It is its own, stand-alone game for the price of a Call of Duty map pack. It looks good, has about the same length as Medal of Honor, and it has four-player Co-Op. The problem is just that, in this day and age, when you can get a retail game for the same price during a Steam daily deal, NZA simply does not hold a candle to the competitors. The game isn't great, some will argue that it isn't even good. I had fun with it, but I purchased it knowing what I was getting into. If you're desperate for more Co-operative zombie action, then you might want to try it out. But if you're new to the genre, you might as well pick up Left 4 Dead 2 instead.

Feels shallow so far, not much to say about it.  If you really like the Sniper Elite series, it is a decent addition, but there are some significant issues.

I have played with both a mouse and KB, as well as an Xbox controller, and I find the controlls when aiming to be top notch, but while moving....

Ok, so the guy runs, but if I am not facing an item directly, he will not pick it up. If I am not facing it correctly, it won't bring up the interaction button for opening doors or searching enemies.  Again, if you are not DIRECTLY facing the specific part of a wall that allows a vault, he will not vault.  THIS IS CRUCIAL!!!

Why is this so annoying do you ask?  Let me digress a bit...

In past Sniper games, there is much SNEAKING and PLANNING.
In THIS Sniper game, there is much running, and alot less planning.  The zombies come at you in hoards, often with the section you are in being blockaded so you are limited on where you can front an attack.  This does not work well with zombies that do not try to hide, they just keep following you.

So while you are busy trying to find a good spot to shoot from, you are constantly having to pop a couple and GO!  You cannot stand still for long.

I was expecting more room for strategy, and so far the game is kind of boring me.  Not too much story yet, and like I said, strategy is not really given time to happen.

If you enjoy the bullet time of Sniper Elite, it is fun to watch zombies get ripped apart.
But if you like the sneaking and SNIPER feel to the gameplay, do not expect it so much here.

Pick it up on sale, but remember that it is gonna feel like an arcade game, rather than a good Sniper experience.

In what appears to be par for the Sniper Elite series, Nazi Zombie Army suffers from a notable lack of imagination.  Departing from even the regular series stream (which I actually prefer, and which I have enjoyed, as the 'sniper' designation fits those games very well), this is an almost entirely 'shoot em up' based game, which appears to ditch the sniper aspect of the series, referring you instead to level after level of 'survive this horde by blasting them away'.  There's such a serious lack of strategy here, that - after logging in about 5 hours total - I don't think I've been able to play through an entire round (of killing endless mobs of nearly identical enemies), without becoming strikingly bored and disinterested.  Much like the Dead Island series fell flat, and brought its share of disrepute to the zombie/undead game genre, this is a similarly forgettable addition to the zombie gaming series.  For future developers - the golden rule of content in gaming is; if you have nothing unique to add to a genre beyond a mildly entertaining shoot-em-up action game, then you'd best leave it to the developers who have real experience and expertise in the genre, instead of wading into an unfamiliar genre with mixed results at best.  Final verdict - this game is at the level of a free DLC, and little more.

For anyone who loves L4D2, especially if you prefer the harder difficulties, this game is for you.

90% of the zombies are slow-moving, which is nice, but the difficulty makes up for it. Instead of shooting wildly, you MUST be accurate with your head shots. Weapons are realistic and ammo hard to find: you must search dead bodies for clips (before they disappear, of course).

Still not hard enough? How about running suicide bomber zombies?
No? How about zombie snipers that can jump between buildings?

If you want a zombie game that delivers you crazy hordes, and requires shooting skills, this is your game.
One downside: not a lot of co-op games running, so you may need to end up convincing friends to buy and play.

This game is great fun. It's about as basic as a game can get - survive the waves of zombies as you make your way through the levels. However what makes it stand out is the sheer mindless fun of getting headshot after headshot as well as the killcam that shows you gratuitous shots of your bullets smashing through zombie skulls - it never gets old and each one is gorier than the last. The level design and graphics are very pretty and it's set up to make you feel increasingly tense as the armies of zombies slowly close in on you.\n\nAs a budget title this game is worth every cent and it is a hell of a lot more polished and addictive than the COD zombie mode. Anyone who likes zombie games should buy it right now!

I am so disapointed in this. Sniper Elite V2 is a great game and a blast to play, but this doesn't use anything that made its base game great.
Why they took a game about carefully planning your sniping targets, getting into position, and hiting pinpoint targets and then turned it into a game where you almost never get a chance to snipe anything, I have no idea.
They even taunt you with interesting sniping targets (like skeletons with still beating hearts), except they spawn those in groups of 4 or more, 30 feet away, and they immedatly start running at you.
I paid only $5 for this game and I'm still feeling a bit ripped off.
